section.title: Creating the website structure

Run publican create_site, specifying the following parameters:

listitem.para: --site_config — the name of the configuration file for your site, with the filename extension .cfg
--db_file — the name of the SQLite database file for your site, with the filename extension .db
--toc_path — the path to the directory in which you will place your documents

step.para: On a computer with an operating system other than Linux, also set:

listitem.para: --temp_path — the path to the templates/ directory of your Publican installation. On computers with Windows operating systems, this is typically %SystemDrive%\%ProgramFiles%\Publican\templates.

step.para: You might give names to the site configuration file and database file that help you to recognize the site to which they belong. For example, for the FooMaster documentation site, you might call these files foomaster.cfg and foomaster.db. You can set --toc_path to whatever you choose.
Edit the site configuration file to specify the name of the site, the web host, and optionally, search parameters for the site:
Specify the title with the title parameter, for example:
Normally, visitors to your website do not see this title because the site's JavaScript redirects them to a homepage. However, this title is likely to be found and indexed by search engines.
Specify the web host with the web_host parameter as a full URL, including the protocol (for example, http://). For example:

Publican uses the value set for web_host to construct the URLs in the XML Sitemap that it creates for search engine crawlers, and to limit searches submitted through the search box in the navigation menu to results on your site only.

Optionally, construct a search engine query to use with the search box in the navigation menu and specify the entire content of a HTML <form> with the web_search parameter. If you do not specify a custom web search, Publican creates a Google search limited to the host that you specified in the web_host parameter.
For example, to construct a Yahoo! search limited to docs.example.com, set:
step.programlisting:
web_search: '
'
step.para: Refer to the documentation of your chosen search engine for details of how to construct custom searches.
If you set value="###Search###" in the code for a submit button, Publican uses the word Search on the button, localized into any language that Publican supports.

important.title: Important — the web_search parameter is not validated
important.para: Publican does not validate the web_search parameter, but builds the value of this parameter into the navigation menu exactly as you specify it. Be especially careful when you use this feature.
